Yes, there are many examples of Behavioral Law and Economics (BLE) studies that have used experiments run on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Here are a few examples:

1. "When Does Regulation Distort Values? Lessons from the Regulation of Kidney Exchange" by Alvin E. Roth and H. Umit Gurbuz: This study used an experiment on MTurk to investigate how regulations can affect the values that people place on goods and services. The experiment involved asking participants to indicate their willingness to pay for the chance to receive a kidney transplant, under different regulatory regimes.
2. "Is the Endowment Effect a Reference Effect? Evidence from a Field Experiment" by Uri Gneezy and John List: This study used an experiment on MTurk to investigate whether the endowment effect is a reference effect, which occurs when people use a reference point to evaluate their options. The experiment involved asking participants to choose between a mug and a pen, either before or after they received the mug as a gift.
3. "Fairness and the Development of Inequality Acceptance" by Jeffrey Butler and Luigi Guiso: This study used an experiment on MTurk to investigate how people's perceptions of fairness influence their attitudes toward income inequality. The experiment involved asking participants to distribute a hypothetical income between themselves and a partner, under different distribution rules and information conditions.

These studies demonstrate how experiments run on MTurk can be used to investigate a wide range of questions in the field of Behavioral Law and Economics.
